Award.AwardTitle: Exploration of the Earliest Crust Forming Events on Earth
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposed work uses new instrumental techniques to measure daughter radionuclides of short-lived and naturally extinct radioactive isotopes of Samarium (Sm) and Hafnium (Hf) to understand formation of the Earth?s early continental crust. The work will examine 4.4 billion-year-old components contained within 3.8-4 billion-year-old host rocks and zircon minerals of the Acasta Gneiss Complex in the Slave Craton of northern Canada, the oldest known body of rock on Earth. Understanding of the formation of the early Earth has broad implications for the breadth of Earth Sciences, ranging from inferring the origin of life to understanding the formation of economic mineral deposits, especially those originating only in older Earth crust or mantle (such as the diamond deposits in northern Canada). When Earth differentiation led to the formation of continental crust is a fundamental problem in understanding planetary evolution of the highest order. The work would primarily be done by a promising, early-career post-doc under the mentorship of the two PI?s at an institution renowned for both analytical innovation and excellence as well as the training of young geochemists who have typically go on to highly productive careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Continents are a unique feature on Earth compared to any other terrestrial planet.  Their high elevation over the ocean floor is due primarily to their distinctly silica-rich, or granitic, average composition compared to the denser, magnesium-rich basaltic rocks of the oceanic crust.  Besides providing a dry surface for land-based life to evolve, the composition of continents and their presence above sea level likely moderates Earth?s climate by providing a draw-down of atmospheric carbon-dioxide concentrations via rock weathering.  The mechanism of continent formation in the modern world is well connected with regions where surface tectonic plates are sinking back into Earth?s interior, called subduction zones, a component of the plate tectonic cycle on Earth.  The sinking, generally oceanic, plate carries water into the interior that both lowers the melting point of the rocks in Earth?s mantle and leads the composition of those melts to be enriched in silica.  This is the cause of the volcanism that occurs along, for example, the Pacific Ring of Fire.  This process creates new continental crust, but such additions are built up around central cores of very old rocks, some dating to more than 4 billion years old.  How these initial continental cores came to be remains a question without a clear answer, yet an answer is fundamental to both the origin of continents and when plate tectonics started on Earth.

This project collected, performed chemical analyses, and determined the ages of a wide selection of rocks from one of the oldest sections of these continental cores, the Slave Craton of the Northwest Territories of Canada (see figure).  Ancient rocks here cover an area of well over 200,000 km2 and span a wide age range, from 4.02 to 2.71 billion years.  The oldest rock unit in the area, the 4.02-billion-year-old Idiwhaa gneiss, appears to have been newly created by removal of melts directly from the mantle, perhaps in an analogous fashion to the way that modern Iceland formed.  In contrast, rocks with ages between 3.6 and 3.9 billion years show evidence of being formed by the remelting of older crustal rocks, perhaps dating back to as old as 4.2 billion years.  This signature of >4 billion-year-old crust, however, is restricted to a relatively small proportion of the western edge of the region of old rocks.  The rocks in this area have seen many investigations since the discovery of the >4 billion-year-old rock in the early 1990?s.  The much larger expanse of slightly younger, though still very old, rocks to the east has seen much more limited study. 

In the summer of 2016, we collected a wide range of rocks from this eastern area, known as the Central Slave Basement Complex, or CSBC (see figure).  Our data confirm previous studies that rocks in the CSBC range in age from 2.71 to 3.32 billion years old.  More importantly, our chemical and isotopic results show that essentially all the rocks in the CSBC represent new crust generated over short time scales by melting of Earth?s mantle.  Coupling these new data with the data we, and others, generated in the older rocks to the west shows a major change in the mechanism of crust formation at around 3.6 billion years ago.  Prior to 3.6 billion, most of the rocks, except for the very oldest, appear to have been generated by reworking of even older crust without much new input from Earth?s mantle.  After 3.6 billion years, however, the majority of the continental crust in this region was created by melting of Earth?s mantle, with the signature of interaction with older crust increasing towards the west.  Our simplified model for the creation of one of the oldest, and largest, expanses of old continent on Earth is that sometime between 4.02 and 4.2 billion years ago, melting of Earth?s interior, possibly in a setting like modern Iceland, produced a thick pile of magnesium-rich, basaltic rocks.  Over the period from 4.02 to ~3.6 billion years, this thick pile of basaltic rocks interacted with water and was heated at the base of the pile to above its melting point, leading to the formation of small volumes of the more silica-rich rocks typical of continental crust.  At 3.6 billion years, the nature of crust formation changed dramatically, beginning nearly a billion years of rapid production of ~200,000 km2 of silica-rich crust.  This transition may record the initiation of something like modern plate tectonics where sinking of oceanic plates around the margins of the large volcanic pile represented by > 3.6 billion-year-old rocks of the Slave Craton led to the type of relatively rapid continent-forming volcanism seen in the present day all around the margins of the Pacific Ocean in areas such as the Cascades, the Andes, and the Aleutians.
